summary: This is an internal U.S. Attorney's Office memorandum notifying the Office of the Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General about the planned release of approximately 2,700 pages of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) documents related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and suicide to The New York Times. The release is mandated by a FOIA litigation deadline and follows deferred prosecution agreements with the two guards accused of falsifying records.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide by hanging while housed in the Special Housing Unit at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Deferred Prosecution Agreements with Guards
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York entered into deferred prosecution agreements with correctional officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, who were accused of falsifying records on the night of Epstein's suicide.

events.title: Planned Document Release to NY Times
events.description: The USAO-SDNY plans to release approximately 2,700 pages of BOP documents related to Epstein's incarceration and suicide to The New York Times pursuant to a FOIA litigation court order.

keyFacts: Approximately 2,700 pages of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) documents related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and suicide were scheduled for release on July 2, 2021.
The documents were previously withheld due to the criminal prosecution of guards Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, which concluded with deferred prosecution agreements in May 2021.

The documents to be released include internal BOP memoranda on the suicide's circumstances, Epstein's psychological records, the autopsy report, and emails showing confusion and a lack of information on the day of the suicide.

A notable item among the documents is a photograph of a defaced sign in the Special Housing Unit that stated rounds on Epstein were 'mandatory,' signed 'God,' with a question mark added after 'mandatory.'
The autopsy report by the New York City Office of the Medical Examiner concluded Epstein committed suicide by hanging.
